HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 25, 1925

Smoker Plans Discussed. Class Urged
to Attend Commemoration
Day Exercises

So diversified were the opinions
of the sophomores voting on the
eight "best known" men of their
class (exclusive of class officers)
that when the votes had been
counted, it was found that more
men had received votes than were
at the meeting.'No less than fifty
members of the Sophomore class
found favor in the eyes of their
classmates.
Keen competition
characterized the voting, no one
receiving an overwhelming lead.
To Day (although it happened
on Friday) fell the highest honor,
the popular football warrior receiving the highest number of
votes, 25. Keen, with 23 votes,
made second place. Niner and
Harwood each received 21 votes.
Others who definitely received the
honor, are Lord, Stone, and Steinwald.

THE TWENTIETH CENTURY RENAISSANCE
Woodrow Wilson, some years ago while addressing an audience
of educators, remarked that in college "the side shows have crowded
out the main circus," and the varied undergraduate campus activities are
attracting the main body of students. Indeed, since the rapid increase
in the numbers of stude its attending institutions of advanced learning,
the numbers of men coming to college with the intention of pursuing
scholarship as their chief interest during their academic career is lamentably small. A concurrent decline in standards at the majority of col-

THE JORNS HOPKINS NEWS- LETTER, FEBRUARY 25. 1925
NURMI BREAKS RECORD
Continued from page 1

in the first 3,000 yards had netted
him a new record.
Jackson Scholz Wins

-.4

The 100-yard invitation race was
Won by Jackson V. Scholz, Olympic
_star, at the fast time .of 10 seconds.
The Invitation 800 Meter Run was
Won by Leslie. Ray Watson was
second, Dodge third, and Jimmy
Connolly disappointed by trailing
the other stars.
The most popular event of the
evening was the 3,000-Meter Walk,
Won by the great Willie Plant, who
won the applause of the fans on
every lap. He ran across the floor
to his dressing room after finishing
his "walk."
The meet itself was a study of
contrasts. Brawny college men
mingled with ninety-pounders
from the local high .and grammar
schools. The short, choppy running of the sprinters formed a
contrast to the long, slow strides
of the distance men. . Now a long
race would, be run, each man
Watching his pace, and Seeking for
the right time to sprint. Then a
relay or a dash would_ thrill the
vast audience.

INTERESTING HISTORICAL EVENTS

Do You Know
—that John Hancock, as President of Congress, signed the
commission of George Washington as Commander-in-Chief
of the American armies in the
Revolutionary War? The original commission is at Washington, D. C., in the Library of
Congress, Division of Manuscripts, where you may see it at
any time and note the famous
signature.

We suggest that every college
student utilize the first opportunity for a trip to the National
Capital and make a point of
looking at the Declaration of
Independence, Washington's
commission, and other important documents bearing on
American history.
We believe a visit to Washington
makes better Americansofus all.

The John Hancock is particularly interested in
insuring college men and women and obtaining
college graduates for the personnel of the field staff.

Meet Unforgettable

Those who were fortunate
enough to gain admission will not
forget the almost superhuman
feats of the Olympic stars who
competed in their various specialties. In every year in the past,
certain men have been advertised
to appear, but, for some reason or
Other, failed to run. This, however, was not the case last night,
for practically every man who was
scheduled to compete was right on
hand.
FRENCH CLUB DISCUSSES
CONSTITUTION
The members of the French Club
are determined to speak . the language which they are studying with
an appreciable degree of fluency.
To this end Friday's meeting in
room, 112, Gilman Hall, was conducted wholly in French.
An interesting discussion on the
Proposed constitution for the Club,
a declamation, and a literary report
Were features of the meeting. Preparations for the Club's play are
Progressing rapidly.
Meetings of the French Club remind the visitor very strongly of
the meetings of German tradesmen
Which Thackerav describes in one
of his novels. The English writer
tells how the Germans spoke entirely in broken English or French
(luring an evening meeting, in order that they might learn these foreign languages.
HOPKINS' RACING STARS
MAKE DEBUT
Hopkins track men made their
I-925 debut last Wednesday in the
All-Baltimore games.
Richard
Gwynn placed second in the South
Atlantic two mile championship.
Captain Robert Heyn ran third in
the sixty-yard championship
Which was won by Louis A.
Clarke, former Hopkins runner.
Heyn also was entered in the
three hundred yard run, but was
tripped .at the start and forced to
retire. Frank Meredith met with
a similar accident in the quarter
Mile run. The most gratifying
event from a Hopkins standpoint
Was the South Atlantic sixty-yard
championship in which every
Wearer of the Black and Blue who
Was entered qualified for the semifinals, while Captain Heyn and
Block reached the finals.

With Cap nd Pipe
,

oc,RAN

Cd1

and tanned from work in the
open, pipe in mouth,cap pulled well
down—that's the erecting engineer,
as pictured in the magazines, and
generally as found on the job. In an
organization like Westinghouse he
occupies a pivotal place, being responsible for the erection of equipment in the field.
Take him in the electrification
of the Chilean State Railway, for
example—one of the outstanding
electrical projects of recent years.
It included not merely the electrification of i34. miles of steam
lines, but also power and sub-station equipment to convert water
power from the Andes Mountains
into electric current.
In 1922 the first shipment of substation equipment departed—but

ahead of it had already departed a
force of Westinghouse erection engineers. They went to a country that
was a stranger to railroad electrical
operation, and to the installation of
large electrical equipment. In the
I 34 miles of steam railway to be
electrified they encountered every
kind of topographical and engineering condition—curves, grades as
steep as 2% per cent and as long as i 2
miles, bridges extending to 44o feet,
six tunnels, the longest 1,600 feet.
Today,two years later, these same
erection engineers are returning—
returning from a Chile, much of
whose railway traffic is moved by its
water falls; they are returning and
promptly departing again on still
other missions of electrical improvement, at home and abroad.

This advertisement is sixth in a vocational series, outlining the fields
for engineering achievement in the Westinghouse organization.
A copy of the entire series will be sent to anyone requesting it.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 25, 1925

Smoker Plans Discussed. Class Urged
to Attend Commemoration
Day Exercises

So diversified were the opinions
of the sophomores voting on the
eight "best known" men of their
class (exclusive of class officers)
that when the votes had been
counted, it was found that more
men had received votes than were
at the meeting.'No less than fifty
members of the Sophomore class
found favor in the eyes of their
classmates.
Keen competition
characterized the voting, no one
receiving an overwhelming lead.
To Day (although it happened
on Friday) fell the highest honor,
the popular football warrior receiving the highest number of
votes, 25. Keen, with 23 votes,
made second place. Niner and
Harwood each received 21 votes.
Others who definitely received the
honor, are Lord, Stone, and Steinwald.

THE TWENTIETH CENTURY RENAISSANCE
Woodrow Wilson, some years ago while addressing an audience
of educators, remarked that in college "the side shows have crowded
out the main circus," and the varied undergraduate campus activities are
attracting the main body of students. Indeed, since the rapid increase
in the numbers of stude its attending institutions of advanced learning,
the numbers of men coming to college with the intention of pursuing
scholarship as their chief interest during their academic career is lamentably small. A concurrent decline in standards at the majority of col-

NURMI BREAKS RECORD
Continued from page 1

in the first 3,000 yards had netted
him a new record.
Jackson Scholz Wins

-.4

The 100-yard invitation race was
Won by Jackson V. Scholz, Olympic
_star, at the fast time .of 10 seconds.
The Invitation 800 Meter Run was
Won by Leslie. Ray Watson was
second, Dodge third, and Jimmy
Connolly disappointed by trailing
the other stars.
The most popular event of the
evening was the 3,000-Meter Walk,
Won by the great Willie Plant, who
won the applause of the fans on
every lap. He ran across the floor
to his dressing room after finishing
his "walk."
The meet itself was a study of
contrasts. Brawny college men
mingled with ninety-pounders
from the local high .and grammar
schools. The short, choppy running of the sprinters formed a
contrast to the long, slow strides
of the distance men. . Now a long
race would, be run, each man
Watching his pace, and Seeking for
the right time to sprint. Then a
relay or a dash would_ thrill the
vast audience.

INTERESTING HISTORICAL EVENTS

Do You Know
—that John Hancock, as President of Congress, signed the
commission of George Washington as Commander-in-Chief
of the American armies in the
Revolutionary War? The original commission is at Washington, D. C., in the Library of
Congress, Division of Manuscripts, where you may see it at
any time and note the famous
signature.

We suggest that every college
student utilize the first opportunity for a trip to the National
Capital and make a point of
looking at the Declaration of
Independence, Washington's
commission, and other important documents bearing on
American history.
We believe a visit to Washington
makes better Americansofus all.

The John Hancock is particularly interested in
insuring college men and women and obtaining
college graduates for the personnel of the field staff.

Meet Unforgettable

Those who were fortunate
enough to gain admission will not
forget the almost superhuman
feats of the Olympic stars who
competed in their various specialties. In every year in the past,
certain men have been advertised
to appear, but, for some reason or
Other, failed to run. This, however, was not the case last night,
for practically every man who was
scheduled to compete was right on
hand.
FRENCH CLUB DISCUSSES
CONSTITUTION
The members of the French Club
are determined to speak . the language which they are studying with
an appreciable degree of fluency.
To this end Friday's meeting in
room, 112, Gilman Hall, was conducted wholly in French.
An interesting discussion on the
Proposed constitution for the Club,
a declamation, and a literary report
Were features of the meeting. Preparations for the Club's play are
Progressing rapidly.
Meetings of the French Club remind the visitor very strongly of
the meetings of German tradesmen
Which Thackerav describes in one
of his novels. The English writer
tells how the Germans spoke entirely in broken English or French
(luring an evening meeting, in order that they might learn these foreign languages.
HOPKINS' RACING STARS
MAKE DEBUT
Hopkins track men made their
I-925 debut last Wednesday in the
All-Baltimore games.
Richard
Gwynn placed second in the South
Atlantic two mile championship.
Captain Robert Heyn ran third in
the sixty-yard championship
Which was won by Louis A.
Clarke, former Hopkins runner.
Heyn also was entered in the
three hundred yard run, but was
tripped .at the start and forced to
retire. Frank Meredith met with
a similar accident in the quarter
Mile run. The most gratifying
event from a Hopkins standpoint
Was the South Atlantic sixty-yard
championship in which every
Wearer of the Black and Blue who
Was entered qualified for the semifinals, while Captain Heyn and
Block reached the finals.

With Cap nd Pipe
,

oc,RAN

Cd1

and tanned from work in the
open, pipe in mouth,cap pulled well
down—that's the erecting engineer,
as pictured in the magazines, and
generally as found on the job. In an
organization like Westinghouse he
occupies a pivotal place, being responsible for the erection of equipment in the field.
Take him in the electrification
of the Chilean State Railway, for
example—one of the outstanding
electrical projects of recent years.
It included not merely the electrification of i34. miles of steam
lines, but also power and sub-station equipment to convert water
power from the Andes Mountains
into electric current.
In 1922 the first shipment of substation equipment departed—but

ahead of it had already departed a
force of Westinghouse erection engineers. They went to a country that
was a stranger to railroad electrical
operation, and to the installation of
large electrical equipment. In the
I 34 miles of steam railway to be
electrified they encountered every
kind of topographical and engineering condition—curves, grades as
steep as 2% per cent and as long as i 2
miles, bridges extending to 44o feet,
six tunnels, the longest 1,600 feet.
Today,two years later, these same
erection engineers are returning—
returning from a Chile, much of
whose railway traffic is moved by its
water falls; they are returning and
promptly departing again on still
other missions of electrical improvement, at home and abroad.

This advertisement is sixth in a vocational series, outlining the fields
for engineering achievement in the Westinghouse organization.
A copy of the entire series will be sent to anyone requesting it.
